results.title: DoDo buys a space pig
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas, Robert Maxwell, Joseph E. Levine, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
DoDo is a kid with extraordinary powers, and he knows how to use them. When he arrives on earth, DoDo has a series of adventures with Compy the Computer Bird and Professor Fingers, who can invent anything. From Hollywood to Loch Ness, from the Pyramids to Paris, DoDo and his pals have fun at the movies, help Interpol capture some spies, find sunken treasure, visit a rodeo and still have time to keep the world from being sold. In this episode DoDo and Professor Fingers cause havoc at a cosmic animal show when Professor Fingers becomes jealous over DoDo buying a lovable long-eared space pig. Animated by Harold Whitaker, John Smith, Tony Whitehouse, Tony Guy, Bruno Bozzetto, Arthur Humberstone.

results.title: The DNA story
results.creator_credit: Ronald Fouracre, Peter Shaw and VSM Productions
results.brief_description: James Watson and Francis Crick at Cambridge, Maurice Wilkins at King’s College, London and Linus Pauling at Caltech describe the events and research leading to the discovery in 1953 of the double helix as a workable structure for DNA. Concentrates upon the role of chemistry and physics in finding the structure of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Gives some background to the rise of molecular biology and the foundation of crystallography and model building.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ronald Fouracre, Peter Shaw and VSM Productions
results.description: James Watson and Francis Crick at Cambridge, Maurice Wilkins at King’s College, London and Linus Pauling at Caltech describe the events and research leading to the discovery in 1953 of the double helix as a workable structure for DNA. Concentrates upon the role of chemistry and physics in finding the structure of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Gives some background to the rise of molecular biology and the foundation of crystallography and model building.

Gives some background to the rise of molecular biology and the foundation of crystallography and model building.

results.title: DoDo at the rodeo
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas, Robert Maxwell, Joseph E. Levine, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 50 of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
DoDo is a kid with extraordinary powers, and he knows how to use them. When he arrives on earth, DoDo has a series of adventures with Compy the Computer Bird and Professor Fingers, who can invent anything. From Hollywood to Loch Ness, from the Pyramids to Paris, DoDo and his pals have fun at the movies, help Interpol capture some spies, find sunken treasure, visit a rodeo and still have time to keep the world from being sold. In this episode DoDo learns to ride a horse, perform at a rodeo and join in a square dance. Animated by Harold Whitaker, John Smith, Tony Whitehouse, Tony Guy, Bruno Bozzetto, Arthur Humberstone.

results.title: DoDo at the opera
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas, Robert Maxwell, Joseph E. Levine, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
DoDo is a kid with extraordinary powers, and he knows how to use them. When he arrives on earth, DoDo has a series of adventures with Compy the Computer Bird and Professor Fingers, who can invent anything. From Hollywood to Loch Ness, from the Pyramids to Paris, DoDo and his pals have fun at the movies, help Interpol capture some spies, find sunken treasure, visit a rodeo and still have time to keep the world from being sold. In this episode DoDo saves the performance of an opera diva. Animated by Harold Whitaker, John Smith, Tony Whitehouse, Tony Guy, Bruno Bozzetto, Arthur Humberstone.

results.title: The Scientist
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Renaissance”.
Of the profound changes that occured during the Renaissance, none shaped the modern world more than the emergence of science. This program documents the age through a study of the lives and works the scientists such Paracelsus, Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo and others who struggled to create a new vision of the world - a vision still evolving as we learn from interviews with today’s scientists.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group

results.title: The Warrior
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Renaissance”.
This thought-provoking presentation documents how the advent of gunpowder during the Renaissance brought about drastic changes in our perception of war and warriors. Beginning with the medieval knight, the glorious warrior, we see how this noble image was forever lost with the development of grander, more mechanised warfare. This program captures the new horrors of war and emphasises the relevancy of the issues during the Renaissance through interviews with contemporary experts in the field of international warfare.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group

results.title: DoDo and the Touchies
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas, Robert Maxwell, Joseph E. Levine, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 52 of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
DoDo is a kid with extraordinary powers, and he knows how to use them. When he arrives on earth, DoDo has a series of adventures with Compy the Computer Bird and Professor Fingers, who can invent anything. From Hollywood to Loch Ness, from the Pyramids to Paris, DoDo and his pals have fun at the movies, help Interpol capture some spies, find sunken treasure, visit a rodeo and still have time to keep the world from being sold. In this episode DoDo helps the inhabitants on the planet Laugh/Cry who are under threat of invasion by inhabitants of another planet known as the Touchies. Animated by Harold Whitaker, John Smith, Tony Whitehouse, Tony Guy, Bruno Bozzetto, Arthur Humberstone.

results.title: DoDo and the space pirates
results.creator_credit: Joy Batchelor, John Halas, Robert Maxwell, Joseph E. Levine, Anroste Films and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 30 of Series “DoDo: the kid from outer space”.
DoDo is a kid with extraordinary powers, and he knows how to use them. When he arrives on earth, DoDo has a series of adventures with Compy the Computer Bird and Professor Fingers, who can invent anything. From Hollywood to Loch Ness, from the Pyramids to Paris, DoDo and his pals have fun at the movies, help Interpol capture some spies, find sunken treasure, visit a rodeo and still have time to keep the world from being sold. In this episode DoDo is called in to avert trouble from a UFO which he manages to achieve in a non-violent fashion. Animated by Harold Whitaker, John Smith, Tony Whitehouse, Tony Guy, Bruno Bozzetto, Arthur Humberstone.

results.title: The Artist
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Renaissance”.
This outstanding production documents the Renaissance through a study of lives and works of the artists who gave meaning to creative expression. Discover the triumph and trials of Brunelleschi, Leonardo Da Vinci, Michelangelo and other masters. Review the movement of persons from craftsmen to artists and the challenge to unwarranted control by the guilds, the church and affluent patrons. Finally, examine the currency of these issues through interviews with contemporary artists.

results.title: A World reborn
results.creator_credit: Bill Jersey and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Renaissance”.
Presents an excellent overview of history and contribution of the Renaissance. Traces the 300 years of this age from the early ideas of pioneers such as Petrach and Jan Hus, who sparked new ways of thinking, to innovators like Brunelleschi and Maciavelli, to the artistic, scientific and political revolutions of the High Renaissance, to the years when Europe finally accepted a vision of the world that was changed forever.
